title: Emmanuel Dennis reveals Cristiano Ronaldo inspired his Real Madrid celebration
text:
Club Brugge forward Emmanuel Dennis has revealed why he appeared to troll Real Madrid on Tuesday by copying Cristiano's Ronaldo trademark celebration at the Bernabeu.

The Nigeria international, 21, bagged a brace in the 2-2 draw and marked his Champions League goals by re-enacting Ronaldo's iconic 'Siii' celebration in front of the Real fans.

Dennis said it was his long-standing admiration for the Portuguese superstar which gave him the motivation to celebrate like his hero.

Club Brugge's Dennis trolled Real Madrid ☠️ by doing the Ronaldo Celebration.pic.twitter.com/R1sFEpjCId — Bet9ja (@Bet9jaOfficial) October 2, 2019

Emmanuel Dennis wheels away in celebration after scoring for Club Brugge vs Real Madrid

Man of the moment Dennis preparing to perform the Cristiano Ronaldo 'Siii' celebration

The Nigerian took full advantage of Real Madrid 's fragile defence, causing havoc all night

Dennis insisted his side's brave showing at the Bernabeu was not down to luck, but tactics

Dennis lay on the Bernabeu turf after his eye-catching celebration to soak up the atmosphere

'I've been a Cristiano fan forever and I was very upset when he left Madrid,' Dennis commented after the game.

'So I decided that if I scored in the Bernabeu, that's what I'd do.

'Everyone expected them to beat us easily. We prepared for them, we believed and we had a good feeling.'

Cristiano Ronaldo invented the now-famous 'Siii' celebration which he started at Real Madrid

Ronaldo has continued his famous routine at Juventus after he moved to Turin in July 2018

Dennis and South Africa's Percy Tau posed problems for the hosts' defence all game, and the Nigerian star admitted Brugge targeted the Real backline as part of their tactics.

'We train a lot, we train hard and we came here to make Ramos and Varane run,' Dennis added.

'They are defenders – defenders don't like to run!

'Most teams come here and play in a block, but we broke from the block and worked like mad.'
